body:
### Problem

I failed to find a way a native lsp feature to scroll docs. Apparently you have to enter the docs by pressing the same keymap twice, then scroll normally, and then you also have to jump out of the floating window. I don't like it, because it forces me to use additional keymaps when I just want to scroll down the docs once or twice. I saw someone mentioned that the coc.nvim plugin does have this feature. And from what I've read it jumps into the floating window, scrolls and then jump out of it. Although, when I used it I didn't notice anything like that — it just scrolls, and I loved it. At least `<c-f>` and `<c-b>` worked, and this was enough for me (at least from what I can remember). If a user wants to copy something from the docs, then the double keymap press to hop into it can still be used. I also didn't find how to scroll docs when using nvim-cmp, I only know that I can scroll it up and down with Lua API (autocompletion docs in insert mode), but it doesn't work for Neovim's LSP hover docs window.

Related links:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/15092
https://github.com/hrsh7th/nvim-cmp/issues/1410

### Expected behavior

The feature can be implemented in 2 ways, I suppose:
1. add a scroll function that would do "jump in, scroll, jump out" action
2. add a proper docs scroll for a floating window without entering it

The first one should be much easier. The second probably would require quite a bit of discussion about which windows can be scrolled this way and the API.

I haven't used VS Code in a long time, but I bet you can scroll in the floating windows there, when you hover over something. I think this feature is essential for the DX, and I am constantly reminded that it doesn't exist when I want to use it.

Implementing such a utility function won't be difficult and users could easily write one similar to [cmp's `docs_view:scroll()`](https://github.com/hrsh7th/nvim-cmp/blob/main/lua/cmp/view/docs_view.lua#L121) in their config. It's not specific to LSP hover but scrolling floating windows in general. This could be a part of #25514 if we wanted to include that into Nvim core.

One workaround that you can use even currently is to use mouse: scrolling the wheels when the mouse pointer is over the floating window will make the (floating) window scrolled.

> It's not specific to LSP hover but scrolling floating windows in general.

Yes. The second point was about that. A general solution that can be obviously used for non-hover-docs stuff. Though a dedicated `vim.lsp.buf.scroll_docs(number)` would be super convenient. It probably will include some additional logic, like automatically using the docs window that appeared after the call of `vim.lsp.buf.hover()`.

> One workaround that you can use even currently is to use mouse

This workaround only works if I use a mouse, and I don't use a mouse. I use touchpad, but even it I use very rarely. Also, IMO, using mouse to scroll in docs window is probably slower than going into the docs window with an additional keymap (then scrolling with keymaps) and jumping out of it after with another keymap.

I think the crux of the issue is keymap scoping and window identification.

> Implementing such a utility function won't be difficult and users could easily write one similar to [cmp's `docs_view:scroll()`](https://github.com/hrsh7th/nvim-cmp/blob/main/lua/cmp/view/docs_view.lua#L121) in their config. 

Looking through cmp's implementation the way it's done is by using `nvim_buf_set_keymap` when creating the pmenu and help doc float and then removing the keymaps with `nvim_buf_del_keymap` when those windows close. It's much less tricky when you have ownership of creating the window itself. 

The only way I can think of to implement this with floating windows you aren't creating yourself is to create an autocommand to detect that the window you care about has been opened or closed. Or to override the creation of the float yourself. It's especially difficult with lsp float doc windows because there isn't anything I'm aware of that makes them objectively identifiable.

@Andrew15-5
Finally took some time this afternoon and figured out how to do this.

I looked into nvim-cmp's implementation for hover docs again, but it turned out to be fruitless for creating keymaps for hover documentation floating windows.

Turns out that noice.nvim had already solved this problem in a relatively straightforward way.
Further, MariaSolOs wrote an even more simplified version of noice's implementation.

Enough preamble, here's how to do it.

First we need a function to get the height of the buffer in the floating window:

> From [noice](https://github.com/folke/noice.nvim/blob/0cbe3f88d038320bdbda3c4c5c95f43a13c3aa12/lua/noice/util/nui.lua#L156)

```lua
--- Returns the height of the buffer in the window
---@param winnr integer
---@return integer
local function win_buf_height(winnr)
  local buf = vim.api.nvim_win_get_buf(winnr)

  -- handle nowrap
  if not vim.wo[winnr].wrap then
    return vim.api.nvim_buf_line_count(buf)
  end

  local width = vim.api.nvim_win_get_width(winnr)

  -- Compute the height of the buffer in the window
  local lines = vim.api.nvim_buf_get_lines(buf, 0, -1, false)
  local height = 0
  for _, l in ipairs(lines) do
    height = height + math.max(1, (math.ceil(vim.fn.strwidth(l) / width)))
  end
  return height
end
```

Then we need a function to scroll the documentation window:

> Also from [noice](https://github.com/folke/noice.nvim/blob/0cbe3f88d038320bdbda3c4c5c95f43a13c3aa12/lua/noice/util/nui.lua#L238)

```lua
--- Scrolls the window by delta lines
---@param winnr integer
---@param delta integer
local function scroll(winnr, delta)
  local info = vim.fn.getwininfo(winnr)[1] or {} -- get the window info
  local top = info.topline or 1 -- get the top line
  local buf = vim.api.nvim_win_get_buf(winnr) -- get the buffer
  top = top + delta -- add the delta
  top = math.max(top, 1) -- set the minimum line number to 1
  -- set the maximum line number to the height of the buffer
  top = math.min(top, win_buf_height(winnr) - info.height + 1)

  vim.defer_fn(function()
    vim.api.nvim_buf_call(buf, function() -- call the function in the buffer
      -- scroll the buffer
      vim.api.nvim_command('noautocmd silent! normal! ' .. top .. 'zt')
      -- trigger the WinScrolled autocmd
      vim.api.nvim_exec_autocmds('WinScrolled', { modeline = false })
    end)
  end, 0)
end
```

Then we need to override `vim.lsp.handlers[vim.lsp.protocol.Methods.textDocument_hover]` with our own float handler. This will give us access to the bufnr and winnr of the floating window, which we need in order to attach our keymaps to the buffer.

> Adapted from [Maria's nvim config](https://github.com/MariaSolOs/dotfiles/blob/1579441d9a805758861d6452d7b45bde5053a7f6/.config/nvim/lua/lsp.lua#L207)

```lua
--- Overrides the default LSP floating window handler to add keymaps and window options.
---@param handler fun(err: any, result: any, ctx: any, config: any): integer?, integer?
---@return fun(err: any, result: any, ctx: any, config: any)
local function float_handler(handler)
  local limit = vim.o.lines * 0.5 -- limit the height of the floating window
  return function(err, result, ctx, win_config) -- the new handler
    local bufnr, winnr = handler(
      err,
      result,
      ctx,
      --- Override the default lsp floating window configuration
      vim.tbl_deep_extend('force', win_config or {}, {
        border = 'rounded',
        -- set the max height of the floating window
        max_height = math.floor(limit),
        -- set the max width of the floating window
        max_width = math.floor(vim.o.columns * 0.4),
      })
    )

    -- return if the buffer or window is not created
    if not bufnr or not winnr then
      return
    end

    -- set the window's scrolloffset to 0
    vim.wo[winnr].scrolloff = 0

    -- stylua: ignore start
    vim.keymap.set('n', '<C-S-N>', function() scroll(winnr, 4) end, { buffer = true })
    vim.keymap.set('n', '<C-S-P>', function() scroll(winnr, -4) end, { buffer = true })
    -- stylua: ignore end
  end
end

vim.lsp.handlers[vim.lsp.protocol.Methods.textDocument_hover] = float_handler(vim.lsp.handlers.hover)

```

This is a pretty hacky solution IMO, but it does work.
If anyone has a better approach to this problem I would love to see it.

Until this is added to neovim core, if someone is already using `noice` it supports scrolling the hover window without entering: https://github.com/folke/noice.nvim#lsp-hover-doc-scrolling

> Until this is added to neovim core,

It won't be. The `KK` idiom is a very nice, ergonomic compromise.

> you have to enter the docs by pressing the same keymap twice, then scroll normally, and then you also have to jump out of the floating window. I don't like it, because it forces me to use additional keymaps when I just want to scroll down the docs once or twice

You don't like `K<c-f>`, so you are requesting that the LSP defaults claim `<c-f>` while the doc hover is visible? And then we would have the inverse problem, which is that now `<c-f>` doesn't do what it's supposed to do, for people who expect it to behave normally. 

You are asking for "docs hover visible" to be a special mode. You can already opt-in to that "mode" by hitting `KK`. Or use the mouse scroll, which already works as you expect.

# Proposal

We could improve the situation by making it easy to exit the popup (*when it's focused*), perhaps mapping (buffer-local in the popup) one or more of `K`, `<esc>`, `<tab>`.

Edit: `q` already serves that purpose: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30347

> The `KK` idiom is a very nice, ergonomic compromise.

Counterpoint: the `KK` idiom only seems ergonomic because you're used to it and you've accepted its limits.

From what I can tell, once users open a hover window with `K`, they only want to be able to do two things: (1) scroll through the text in the window and (2) close the window. Compare this with a code split, where users will likely want to edit and delete text in both parts of the split. Or even compare it with a split showing `:help`, where users often want to jump around using `:helptags`. Correct me if I'm wrong, but it never makes sense to (try to) edit, delete, or navigate the text in a hover window opened by `K`. (Maybe sometimes it makes sense to yank the text from such a window? I've never done it, but other people may.)

Right now, the only built-in way to do (1) or (2) is the `KK` idiom, and so—yes—the idiom is helpful. But this thread, the plugin code in `noice`, the user configuration code quoted here, and [Stackexchange questions like this one](https://vi.stackexchange.com/q/37225), suggest that (many?) people would like to be able to scroll the text in the window and close the window *without ever entering the window*.

> # Proposal
> We could improve the situation by making it <easier?> to exit the popup, perhaps mapping `K` and/or `<esc>` and/or `<tab>`.

+1 There's definitely some demand for this. See, e.g., the [Stackexchange question I linked above](https://vi.stackexchange.com/q/37225). (Also, there seem to be several ways to exit the hover window once you are in it: at least `q`, `:q`, and `:bd` work. Are those documented somewhere? I figured them out through trial and error, but maybe I missed some obvious docs.)

I'd argue that it would be an even bigger improvement if it were possible to close the floating window without entering it. Using some of the code from this thread, here's how I handle that currently.

```lua
---Closes a floating window without entering it.
---@param win_id integer
local close_window = function(win_id)
    if not vim.api.nvim_win_is_valid(win_id) then
        vim.keymap.del("n", "<Leader>;", { buffer = true })
        return
    end
    vim.api.nvim_win_close(win_id, false)
end

--- Overrides the default LSP floating window handler to add keymaps and window options.
---@param handler fun(err: any, result: any, ctx: any, config: any): integer?, integer?
---@return fun(err: any, result: any, ctx: any, config: any)
local function float_handler(handler, focusable)
    -- Omitted code...

    return function(err, result, ctx, config) -- the new handler
        -- Omitted code...
        local bufnr, winnr = handler(err, result, ctx, config)

        -- Return if the buffer or window is not created.
        if not bufnr or not winnr then
            return
        end

       -- Omitted code and keymaps...
        vim.keymap.set("n", "<Leader>;", function()
            close_window(winnr)
        end, { buffer = true })
    end
end

vim.lsp.handlers["textDocument/hover"] =
    float_handler(vim.lsp.handlers.hover, false)
```

 As someone says much earlier in the discussion, this isn't so difficult. But it took me a long time to put together all the pieces of how to do it. I definitely think it would improve the UX of these floating windows if users didn't have to enter a hover window to close it (or scroll it, for that matter).

> From what I can tell, once users open a hover window with K, they only want to be able to do two things: (1) scroll through the text in the window and (2) close the window. 

That assumption is wrong. They may also want to yank text for copy&pasting or a web search.

> I'd argue that it would be an even bigger improvement if it were possible to close the floating window without entering it.

Most floats close on `CursorMoved`, which I'd argue to be the least friction anyway.

> That assumption is wrong. They may also want to yank text for copy&pasting or a web search.

Fair enough.

> Most floats close on `CursorMoved`, which I'd argue to be the least friction anyway.

Also fair enough, but I know from experience that many people would rather not have to move the cursor just to close (this) float. (Yes, you can map something to move one character and then right back, but the desire to do that seems to prove my point)

Not every desire is reasonable or worth the added code, documentation, tests, and/or maintenance. The difference between (mapping) `jk` and `<esc>` (or `K` or whatever you want -- I don't expect there's a universal preference!) does _not_ meet that threshold, no matter how loud the request.

Okay, I yield. I just wanted to add my two cents since I've seen this question/desire come up a lot, this thread was open, and Justin seemed open to making some adjustments to the current UX. Thanks for the feedback.

> Justin seemed open to making some adjustments to the current UX

Yes, but specifically about closing an _active_ float, not closing/acting on a visible but inactive float. Mapping `<esc>` _in the float_ to close it would indeed be a reasonable UX improvement. (It's much harder to close inactive floats, because which one would you want to target? Every time you think you have a clear answer, someone will come up with another edge case where that would be wrong ;))

## Status/Resolution/Summary

As documented in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30347, 

- to show the docs, hit `K`
- to scroll the hover, just hit `K` followed by however you prefer to scroll (`<c-d>`, `<c-u>`, etc)
- to quit the hover, hit `q` while the hover is focused. the hover already auto-closes on cursor moved, too.
- mouse scroll works in the hover.
